original_speakers: NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR PATEL
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR HATTINGH
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR BLACK

testimony: I beg leave to call Mr Livingstone Lukhele.
Mr Lukhele, what language would you prefer to use?

I would speak Zulu.
LIVINGSTONE M. LUKHELE: (sworn states)
Mr Lukhele, where were you born?
Have you lived all your life in Ermelo?
At the time of the commission of the offences for which you claim amnesty, what was your occupation?
And at that time, were you a member of any political organisation?
I beg your pardon, which political party did you belong to?
Were you an office bearer or just an ordinary member?
According to the schedule on page 22, you claim amnesty for firstly the murder of Obed Nhlabathi, do you confirm that?
That occurred in August 1992?  You also claim amnesty for the murder of Bhe Malinga in October 1993, is that correct?
Thirdly you claim amnesty for the attempted murder of unknown members of the South African Police in November 1993, is that correct?
And finally you claim amnesty for the illegal possession of firearms and ammunition.  Is that correct?

Mr Patel, how do we solve our problem with unknown members of the South African Police?  We don't know names and we don't know numbers.
	I don't ask this question because I think you've got a problem, I just want to know how we are going to phrase in the event of us granting amnesty, how are we going to phrase that because if for example there were five Policemen, then we grant amnesty because he says there were four.  Can he be prosecuted for the fifth one and if he is prosecuted, who is that fifth one?
I would like to have said that that is the Committee's problem, but ...
I told you the other day, we can pass the ball well enough.  We just refuse amnesty.

What I would like to say is the evidence will be led that this particular incident was a shoot-out with Policemen, that the applicant was involved in and perhaps instead of granting amnesty if amnesty is going to be granted, rather than mentioning the number of Policemen involved, rather to mention the particular incident, on that date, this is what happened and for that particular offence.

And perhaps cultured in terms of all the Policemen who were involved in that particular incident?
	Maybe, I will have to give it some thought.

Question Mr Patel, perhaps you should also look at the particular statutory crimes relating to political violence at the time, that may be able to assist you.
	That is also just a suggestion, I am not saying it is necessarily so.

I see in his application here, perhaps your Attorney might be able to help you, she, I understand it is, it looks like her handwriting, as it is the case with the other applicants gone by already, question 9(c)(iv), page 135, any other information which assist in identifying and locating victims, if the South African Police in Ermelo could assist, I am not too sure, maybe that is the answer, I don't know.

I will certainly look into it and see if she can assist in any of it Mr Chairman.
	Thank you.  Let's deal firstly with the murder of Obed Nhlabathi.  This is the gentleman that was killed in the hospital, am I correct?
What was your motivation with regard to the killing of Obed?
He was killed for political reasons.
Was he killed because of an express instruction received from anybody?
Yes, there were instructions, but the instructions were not direct.
Could you tell the Committee what instructions you had received?
It was an implied order that I received.
Yes, and what was the implication?  What was told to you?
As a member of the SDU, my duty was to protect members of the community so that we could restore peace.
This came from Mr Gushu during our discussion.
Now, did you know Mr Nhlabathi prior to his death?
He was a member of Inkatha.
Had he been identified by anybody as being a trouble maker?
We already knew that he was one of the persons perpetrating the violence, ourselves as the community were conducting our own research.

Mr Patel, not that it is a requirement in which absence the application could be fatal, I am not suggesting that, but where in his statement does he give the details as to what happened in the hospital?  I don't seem to find it.

Mr Chairman, at some stage and I think most appropriately at the stage of argument, I will have to address the Committee with regard to what is contained in this statements, why there were two background statements, etc, etc.

I accept that.  If you remember when Khaba gave evidence, this witness became a central figure, not a central figure, but he became or his actions became a feature of what occurred in the hospital.  For what it is worth, I don't know whether this is going to effect our findings at the end of the day, I haven't discussed it with my colleagues yet, but there was an issue of whether he was stabbed or shot.
	At some time I think Khaba said well if he was stabbed, I don't know about it, but Livingstone may be able to shed light on that and when one looks at both original form and the supplementary statement, I am not too sure whether it is (indistinct), on page 134, he claims to have stabbed somebody but the details are not too clear.
	That is the closest it comes.
I don't want to give evidence for the applicant, but the ...
Maybe it will help to ask him and place it before us.
Yes, I will get there Mr Chairman.  Mr Lukhele, your act of assisting in the murder of Mr Nhlabathi, where did that occur?
It started at Extension and went as far as the hospital at Ermelo.
I think it is probably necessary for you to tell us what happened in the Extension?  At the Extension, what happened?
When we went out to the Extension, we were going to Bongani's grandmother.
Could you just tell the Committee who do you mean when you say we?
I am referring to Bongani Khaba, myself and Dumsani.

Before we arrived there, we met some people on the road and some people told us that they had a problem at the disco, they were being troubled by the Black Cats and we took the route that would go passed the disco and on our way, one of the Black Cat members came and he was going to walk passed us towards the disco.  I think he must have arrived there first and told them that we were coming.
	I found myself at the hands of another Black Cat member who was handling me.  I was having a jungle knife and I freed myself with this knife, after which myself and Bongani fled, seeing that they had seen us first.
	Gunshots were fired during which time we had already started fleeing.  That is when we came across Obed.  I don't know really how we came to meet him.
Who shot first, do you know?
No, I wouldn't know because I didn't have a gun.  I therefore wouldn't know where came this gun shot.
You were moving away from the disco and you came across Obed, is that correct?
We came across Obed on our way from the disco, but at the time we didn't realise it was him because of the distance.  I only realised it was Obed when we met him at the hospital.
When you came across this person at the disco, did you see Khaba doing any shooting?
You mean when we met Obed?
I saw him shooting at the hospital, but I didn't see him shooting at the disco.
After the incident at the disco, what happened then?  Were any of you injured from the shots that were fired?
Dumsani was shot in the leg, I think his left thigh and we had to rush him home, because he too resided at the Extension.  We took him there from whence he was to be taken to hospital.
Yes, and where did you take him to?
We took him to his home, his parents' home.
Can you tell the Committee how it came to be that you went to the hospital thereafter?

When we left Extension, we went to the Wesselton township where we used to live and informed Mrs Nkosi what had transpired.  She rushed to the hospital to establish what was happening about Dumi, she came back with the information that Black Cats were on their mission to finish him off and we rushed to the hospital.
Dumsani, the same person who was shot on the thigh.
I see.  So you then went to the hospital with Khaba, is that correct?
And tell the Committee what happened when you got there?

When we arrived at the hospital, we spoke to him and he did indicate that yes, such people were here at the hospital.
	Thereafter Bongani Khaba pretended as if he is one of the Black Cat members saying to one of the nurses that he wanted to see Obed.
They gave us the ward number and we proceeded towards the ward, we found him there and we ...
What did you think was going to happen?
Would you please repeat your question.
What did you think was going to happen there when you people went?
I thought that we would meet some of the Black Cats there and we would be in a position to protect Dumi.
Did Khaba not discuss this issue with you when he told the nurses that he was a member of the Black Cats and he wanted to go see Obed?
No, he did not.  I was busy talking to Dumi at the time.
Mr Patel, is this a convenient stage?

As it pleases you Mr Chairman.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
LIVINGSTONE M. LUKHELE: (still under oath)

(continued)   Mr Lukhele, I think we were at the stage where Obed had ascertained from one of the nursing sisters to where, I mean Khaba had ascertained from one of the nursing sisters as to where Obed was.  What happened then?
Exactly what did he ask the nurse?

Bongani Khaba asked the nurse where Obed was, in which ward he was because the hospital is big.
	He was pretending to be a Black Cat member.
Did you know Obed was in the hospital?
We knew when we arrived at the hospital because Mrs Nkosi had already told us.
In her explanation special reference to Dumi, she indicated that Dumi was in danger now that he was in hospital, because the Black Cats were also bringing their member, Obed to the hospital.
As it pleases you Mr Chairman.  Now, having obtained this information, what transpired then?

As I have explained, we arrived at the hospital and we did what we could to get to his bed, hospital bed.  We also discovered that there was another ANC member apart from Dumi who was, I think he had a broken leg.
Did you and Khaba get to the ward where Obed was?
Please tell the Committee what happened in the ward.
On entering the ward, we realised that there were many beds.  We located him and Mr Khaba started shooting him.
Was Mr Khaba successful in his attempts?
As a soldier Obed was trying to duck and dive, but he could not because obviously the bullet is faster than he was.
What part did you play?  Did you do anything?
Could you tell the Committee how many times you stabbed him?
I do not remember.  It may have been twice or three times.
Where on his body did you stab him?
He was trying to block the knife as I was stabbing him.  I think I stabbed him on the shoulders.
Are you not sure you stabbed him?  You may have stabbed at him, did you inflict any injuries?
I think I succeeded because I was not in the position to distinguish between the blood that came out as a result of the gunshot or the stabbing.
Did you stab him after he was shot or before?
Yes, I stabbed him after he had been shot.
In which part of his body was he shot?
I could not see some of the gashes, I was just stabbing.
Where about in his body did the bullets penetrate?

The obvious ones were in the hands, where blood was oozing and there was another blood oozing from his head, but I didn't know where about in the head.    There were no signs of bullet holes on his face.
And you say despite being shot, he was able to ward off stabbing?
He had not died at the time when I was stabbing him, because he was trying to block as I was stabbing him.
Did you see the firearm which Mr Khaba used?
What type of firearm was it?
Do you have any idea where he got it from, did he ever tell you?
We were trying to make sure that Dumi is protected so that his fellow Inkatha members should not find him at the hospital, so that we could protect our ANC members.
Is that the reason you stabbed him?

That is not the only reason.  And also that he was problematic to the community, having been a member of Inkatha and it had already been discussed because he is problematic, he too should be eliminated.
So you were aware of that plan?

As I have explained, ourselves as the youth within the ANC were conducting our own research so as to identify people who were problematic, apart from going to Mzwandile to get information about people who were problematic.
As it pleases you Mr Chairman.    Apart from Obed, was anybody else identified as being problematic?
There is another third one, but I cannot recall his name.
Let's look at the second offence, the murder of Bhe Malinga.  Who was he?
Could you just briefly explain to the Committee how this offence was, the circumstances of this offence?
How should I explain it, on the day of the offence?

We met him at Mdluli Street at Wesselton during the day, around twelve o'clock.  He was headed towards the taxi direction, we don't know where he was headed for.  We managed to discover that he was carrying a gun.
	We needed the gun that he was carrying.
I was with Bongani Khaba and Basil Dhlamini.
Could you tell the Committee how you, did you  manage to get his gun?
How did you manage to do this?

Bhe was trained and he was a member of the SAP and that obviously made him an enemy of the ANC.  I had to shoot him.  I shot him once and when I tried the second time, the gun jammed and Basil also shot him on the  head.  That is when he fell down.
In committing this offence, were you acting under any orders?
Yes, that offence is part and parcel of the order, because it was indicated to us already that our enemy is Inkatha and the Police.

Now, the third offence, the attempted murder of the unknown South African Police members in November 1993.  Obviously you are unable to identify any victims, but could you just shortly explain the circumstances of this event?

On that day, we were at Mndebele's shop, we spoke to Mr Mndebele.  I would also explain that at the time myself and Bongani Khaba and Pelele Shongwe were being wanted by the Police.
	As we were at the shop, one boy came in running, telling us that there was a Police convoy towards the shop direction.  Myself and Basil fled, Pelele remaining behind.  We took a different direction and as we were observing what was happening, they came out with one person who was apparently being forced into their kombi.
	We thought that the person who was being arrested, was Pelele because it was a distance from where we stood.  Myself and Basil started shooting with an aim of destructing the Police, so that they should not take the person into the kombi.

Yes, they fired back at us, but then they had a bigger fire power and they also had automatic assault rifles and we formed a semi-circle.  We took a different street so that we were on the other side above them.
	We came across another group of Police as we were doing that.  We went to a shack during which time we were surrounded by the Police.  We exchanged gunfire with the Police.
	Basil came out of the shack in which we were trying to flee.  That is when he was shot and he died.  Myself and Bongani realised that we no longer had ammunition and we only had one gun.  The other one was with Basil and we decided to surrender.
What motivated you and your fellow comrades to commit this offence?
All of these happened as a result of political reasons.  Police were seen as the enemy of the ANC because of their conduct towards the ANC members and their involvement with Inkatha members.
Did you see this particular offence that you committed, as being part of the general instructions that you had received?
Yes, I saw it as part and parcel of the general instruction which was broad.  It was like an umbrella inclusive of Inkatha and the Police.
You were a member of a Self Defence Unit, is that correct?
Tell me, let's just get clarity here.  Did Khaba make application for the murder of Malinga?

If that is addressed to me Mr Chairman, at this stage no, I will have to take instructions on this.  I will ask that the matter stand down, my cross-examination just stand over, I need instructions on that aspect.  It is the first time that I have heard of it.
Who were the members of your Self Defence Unit?

Those that I still remember very well were myself, Bongani Khaba, Pelele Shongwe and Charlie, including Basil Dhlamini as well as Bheza.  There were many of us but we were not together most of the time.
	I was most of the time in the company of Pelele and Bongani.

Mr Patel, can I just come in here.  I just want to get the complete picture, I am just taking you back a little now.
	Tell me, the gun which you used to shoot Malinga with, was that the same gun which was used to shoot Obed with or which gun was that?
Where did you get this gun from?

After having received the command, the fact that we should arm ourselves, anybody including thugs that we identified as not belonging to the ANC, if such a person had a gun, an illegal gun, we would take it.
	Even if we had an opportunity to take guns from Police, we would do exactly that.
The question I am asking you is where did you get the gun from which you used to shoot Malinga with?
I got it from a tavern at Wesselton, from a person who was drunk, carrying this gun.
The fourth offence for which you claim amnesty is the illegal possession of firearms and ammunition, is this the same gun that we are talking about, that you took off this drunk person at the tavern?
Yes, that is the same gun.
What was your motivation in taking the gun off him?
My aim was to carry out my mission as member of the SDU.
As a member of the ANC, how did you view the situation in Wesselton, Ermelo at the time that you committed these offences?

The situation here was unbearable because there was violence.  Any level headed person would not have tolerated what was happening.
	There was shooting taking place.  Some people were getting injured right before the eyes of other people and this was intolerable.
In committing any of the offences for which you have claimed amnesty, did you act out of any personal malice or financial gain?
No, that is not the case.
If we can just go back to the shoot-out with the South African Police, can you tell the Committee when exactly that incident took place?
The shoot-out between the Police happened on the 11th of November 1993.
Where would it have taken place?
It happened at the first township in Wesselton, the problem is that there is no specific name for that area, whereas the name Wesselton is inclusive, it covers all the townships in the area.

I know that, but I want to know how to identify this incident, because there is no names of Policemen and all I need perhaps is a geographical indication as to where the incident occurred for which you are making amnesty application.
Perhaps if I could assist Mr Chairman, Mr Mndebele's shop, where the shooting commenced, do you know the name of the street?
Chairperson, may the speaker please repeat the question.
Mr Mndebele's shop where the shooting incident first began, do you know the name of the street?
Yes.  The shop is at the corner of Makhwaza and Mabileza Streets.
And where the shooting finally came to an end at the shack, do you know the name of the street where the shack is located?
No.  There are no street names in that area, because people just put up their shacks as well as they wish.
Can you just repeat the names of the streets please?
Corner of Makhwaza and Mabileza Streets.
It was on the 11th of November 1993.
Were you prosecuted for any of the offences in respect of which you claim amnesty?
I was prosecuted yes, for some of the offences.
All right, let's start at the beginning.  Were you prosecuted for the murder of Obed Nhlabathi?
No.  I was not even charged for that one.
Were you prosecuted for the murder of Mr Bhe Malinga?
No, I was not charged for that one as well.
Were you prosecuted for the attempted murder of the unknown South African Police members?
Yes, I went to trial for that one.
The case came to an end, I was not charged or I was not sentenced.
Yes, I can say I was acquitted because that was the one offence that made it difficult for me to be granted a bail.
Did anybody give evidence, did anybody talk at the trial?

The Police were making it difficult for us to be granted bail, because we were kept in the cell from the 11th of November 1993 so that there came the Regional from Pretoria and it discovered that there was not enough evidence to sentence us and we were therefore acquitted.
You appeared in court and you went on trial and you were found not guilty?
Does the same apply to the last offence for which you claim amnesty, namely the illegal possession of firearms and ammunition?
I have no further questions Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR PATEL
I have no questions, thank you.

I don't have any questions, but I have a problem with something.  I don't know if the application form is correct, but on page 138 the person received 28 years.  Is that Mr Lukhele?  This bothers me because the application forms are vague?
Are you in prison at the moment?
Have you been serving any prison sentence?
Are you scheduled to serve any prison sentence?
It would seem that paragraph was filled in wrong.
It would seem so, thank you.  I have no further questions.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS VAN DER WALT
No questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
Just hold on, I want to find out something.  Mr Black, what is your position now?

Mr Chairman, as far as the issue relating to which I have been taken by surprise, Mr Malinga is concerned, I will need to take further instructions from Mr Khaba on that issue and there are other questions which I would put, so I would respectfully submit that if I could deal with it all after Mr Hattingh's matter and then put it.
Mr Hattingh may surprise us and ask two questions, then what?
Then I would request an opportunity to take further instructions.
Okay, Mr Hattingh, the floor is yours.
Are we proceeding?  Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Lukhele, you indicated and you gave names of the people who were part of your SDU.  If you could just repeat the names for me, I would appreciate it.
That is his nickname, I think he is David Majola.
Are you referring to the Majola that is going to come and testify still as Charlie?
Yes, that is the same person.
You mentioned four people now, are there any others?
No.  The ones that were close to me are the ones that I still remember.
You also mentioned a Pelele previously?
Yes, that is Pelele Lawrence Shongwe.  He is also one of the applicants for amnesty.
From this group that you mentioned, the group of five it is Khaba who is an applicant, Majola who is an applicant and Shongwe who is an applicant.
And Gita Mnisi?  Just to confirm, I understood your evidence to be that there was no direct instruction for the killing of Obed?
If you are talking about a direct order, yes, that is correct.
That there was no direct order from any ANC command that Obed was to be killed, is that correct?

I would like to explain that when there were members of the SDU who were instructed to protect and this we did under fighting circumstances.
	This instruction therefore implies that killing is possible and where possible, win over people to the ANC so that they do not become problems.  Therefore the instructions were not strictly that we should go out there and kill, we had to look at the situation.  If the situation warranted, therefore we would intervene.
As far as the second incident is concerned, that is the one of Bhe Malinga, I understood your evidence to be that he was killed because he was an IFP member or Inkatha member, is that correct?
Objection Mr Chairman, the evidence is that Bhe Malinga was a Policeman.  In any event, as I understand Mr Hattingh, he doesn't have any clients who represent Bhe Malinga.

Mr Chairman, the purpose of this cross-examination is to try to find out on what kind of motive did they rely when they killed someone, whether it was purely on the basis of his connection to being an Inkatha member, being a Policemen or whether there were in fact further reason required before they would go ahead and kill someone.

He has answered your questions of that nature in respect of Obed, isn't it?
	Are you representing the family of Malinga as well or not?
No, I don't.  Only with regard to Obed's family.
On what basis would then be able to ask questions in respect of Malinga when you have already got the answer to similar questions in respect to Obed?

Mr Chairman, as I have already indicated, I am trying to test the motives of this applicant, whether he in fact acted at the time with a political motive, and I think it would be, my submission would be for him not to make full disclosure with regard to other incidents where he together with the same people, committed the same kind of crime in the same period, that that would be somewhat artificial.

You know Mr Hattingh, we are going to go through the same thing again.   When you appear on behalf of interested parties, then you deal with their interest only.  If there is nobody who is interested in the Malinga issue, that is that.  I mean it is tough luck, there is nothing we can do about that.
	But to go on an investigation of that sort, does create problems for the other side.

Mr Chairman, I will retract that question, I will put it differently.  Mr Lukhele, from your evidence it would appear and you can assist me if I am wrong, that at times your decision to kill someone, was based on the fact that he belonged to Inkatha, is that correct?

Are you saying if a person is a member of Inkatha or the SAP, I would say it was already known that they were enemies.  I have also indicated that there was already an implied order to the effect that the IFP and the SAP were the enemy, so that if such people were threatening the community, it was therefore our responsibility to eliminate them.

Would you at the time have considered that someone was threatening the community purely on the basis that he was a member of Inkatha or did he have to do something more than to be a member of Inkatha before you would kill him?

I would say to Mr Hattingh, Bongani was Inkatha, Charlie was Inkatha and Basil was Inkatha.  They came to us and we discussed, we did not kill them.  We were not going around killing people because they were just IFP members.
Were you aware of the fact that Obed Nhlabathi and Mdudusi Mutau was awaiting trial, they were arrested and they were awaiting trial for the murder of Khaba's mother?
Were you aware of the fact that Khaba's mother was murdered some six weeks, or that she got killed some six weeks prior to the killing of Obed?
Even though I didn't know, I don't know the length of time, I knew about the death of Khaba's mother.
Did you and Khaba discuss the fact that his mother got killed?
In other words, the killing of Obed, was that the plan of revenge for Obed suspected of having killed Khaba's mother?
Chairperson, we learnt that the Black Cats are the ones that attacked Khaba's mother and they just gave us a plural number as to the people who attacked Khaba's mother.

I put it to you that in fact you assisted Khaba in the killing of Obed, not because Obed was a danger to the community and that you wanted to protect the community, but because of revenge for the killing of Khaba's mother.
If that is how you see it, that is wrong.  That is not correct.
When you went passed the disco that night, could you just explain, were you on your way to the disco initially or was it by chance that you ended up at the disco?
Our main objective was to go and see Bongani's grandmother.
Why then did you go to the disco?

As I have explained, we came across certain people on our way.  People who indicated to us that they were being troubled by the Black Cats at the disco and that is when we rushed to the disco to find out what was happening.
Did you find any problems at the disco when you got there?
Yes, because people ended up getting injured and we too, ran away.

I put it to you that the witness that will be called in this regard, will say that there were no problems at the disco prior to your and Khaba's arrival.
	The only problems that there were, were caused by you when your crowd started shooting.
This is very strange, how could I have shot Dumsani who was my friend.  I could not have taken him and shot him at the disco.
Did you see Obed at the disco at all?
Things happened so fast and the lighting in that area is so poor, there was just no way one could identify people, fast as things were happening.
Had you seen Obed earlier that day?
Is it then correct to say that you only saw Obed for the very first time that day, when you that night went to hospital and found him in his hospital bed?
I thought your question was whether I saw him before on that day or not.  Would you please explain.  Are you referring to that day here or what, would you please explain.
I don't know what you are agreeing to, because you have just asked me about that day or other days, I don't know, I don't understand.

I haven't been talking about any other days, I am talking about the day that the events took place which led to Obed's death.
	Have you seen Obed on that day prior to your killing him, or assisting to kill him in his hospital bed?

I am very sorry, I didn't get your question well.
	I didn't see him on that day before I saw him at the hospital.
Did you personally take part in any fighting at the disco earlier that evening?
The one part that I played, was running away.
As far as I can remember, you in your evidence in chief said that you took out your knife of some sort, some kind.  What was the position with regard to that?
I used the knife so that I could clear my way to run away.
Could you say whether any of the people involved in the fighting at the disco that night, were under the influence of alcohol?  Either your group or the other group?
I would not tell whether they were drunk or not.
Did you at any stage Mr Lukhele, see this people consuming alcohol?
Yes, the people who were in the disco, most of them were the members of the community, therefore I knew them.
Did you see any one of the two groups that were fighting, that is your group and the other side, any one of those people consuming alcohol on that day?
Your friend who got injured that night, did you personally take him to the hospital or did you only accompany him to his own house?

We took him from the scene, because he couldn't walk, we carried him to his home.  He was staying a few streets from the scene.  We left him there so that the people in the house could take him to the hospital.
So when you later that night went to the hospital, that would be the first time that you had gone to the hospital that day, when you killed Obed?
I normally go to the hospital to go and visit sick people, that was not my first time to go to the hospital.
Had you been to the hospital earlier that night before going to the hospital to kill Obed?
Where did you see or meet with Mrs Nkosi?
The report that she made, can you just tell us again, what did she tell you about what was going on at the hospital?
She told me about Dumi's condition and the fact that there were Black Cats who arrived there and tortured Dumi.
What did the Black Cats do to Dumi?
He told me that those people said they were coming back to him again.
Did Mrs Nkosi know that Obed Nhlabathi was already in hospital?
It seemed so because she told us that the people, the Black Cats gang came, they brought Obed and at the same time they went to see Dumi.
Did Mrs Nkosi mention the name of Obed, that he was already in hospital?
Though I can't remember, I am not sure if she did or not.  But we never used to call them with their names, we used to refer to them as the Black Cats.
Well, when was the decision made to kill Obed that night?
The decision to kill Obed, I don't know, I can't remember when was it taken, but I think it was done just before he was killed.  Just before he got killed.
Was the decision taken on your way to the hospital, or only the moments when you got to his bed and you realised that it was Obed in the bed?
No, on that particular day the decision was already taken, the decision to kill him was already taken at that time.

No, we know that, but on the particular day, when you were on your way to the hospital, the Advocate's question is when you were on your way to the hospital, did you know you were going there to kill Obed or did you only realise that Obed was going to get killed, when you saw him in the bed.  Is that the question Mr Hattingh?
